name: Kiosk-server
body:
# Kiosk Instructions

[Photos of the Kiosk](https://www.dropbox.com/sh/o2lyzcw7k0gqw2y/O7WMDO4rcy?v=1mci)

Below you will find all the parts necessary. Rough cost:
- Raspberry Pi: $50
- SD Card: $10
- Monitor: $250
- HDMI cable: $10
- Raspberry Pi Case: $15
- Total: $335

# Bill of Materials

## Required

#### Raspberry Pi

[Amazon](http://www.amazon.com/Raspberry-Pi-Model-Revision-512MB/dp/B009SQQF9C/ref=wl_it_dp_o_nS_nC?ie=UTF8&colid=3GFPJV6W7TJGE&coliid=IUTYDDIG039LJ) 

Can be found for cheaper elsewhere, but not always in stock

#### SD Card

[Amazon](http://www.amazon.com/Transcend-Class-Flash-Memory-TS8GSDHC10E/dp/B003VNKNEG/ref=sr_1_2?s=pc&ie=UTF8&qid=1369802882&sr=1-2&keywords=SD+card)

Any 8GB or bigger SD card should work. Highly preferable to use a class 10 card.

#### HDMI Cable

[Amazon](http://www.amazon.com/AmazonBasics-High-Speed-HDMI-Cable-Meter/dp/B00870ZHCQ/ref=wl_it_dp_o_nS_nC?ie=UTF8&colid=3GFPJV6W7TJGE&coliid=I3F6D1S91J5XNN) 

This is a cheap and effective version. Could use something quite a bit shorter. Also worth checking out monoprice.com

#### Monitor

[Amazon](http://www.amazon.com/ViewSonic-VX2703MH-LED-27-Inch-LED-Lit-Monitor/dp/B008A3KFB8/ref=wl_it_dp_o_nS_nC?ie=UTF8&colid=3GFPJV6W7TJGE&coliid=I1161MFKDHX6BF)

Any monitor with HDMI should work. We have verified the above one works well and is fairly bright. If using above, disable sleep.

#### Raspberry Pi Case

[Amazon](http://www.amazon.com/SB-Raspberry-Pi-Case-Clear/dp/B008TCUXLW/ref=wl_it_dp_o_nS_nC?ie=UTF8&colid=3GFPJV6W7TJGE&coliid=I3016C3L9WU9HZ)

## Optional


#### Wireless Dongle

[Amazon](http://www.amazon.com/Edimax-EW-7811Un-Wireless-Adapter-Wizard/dp/B003MTTJOY/ref=wl_it_dp_o_nS_nC?ie=UTF8&colid=3GFPJV6W7TJGE&coliid=I2CCKLML2DIJO1)

Fully compatible out of the box with the Raspberry Pi. Will require configuration.

# Kiosk Setup

Defering to [these instructions](http://lokir.wordpress.com/2012/09/16/raspberry-pi-kiosk-mode-with-chromium/) for now


### Welcome to GitHub Pages.
This automatic page generator is the easiest way to create beautiful pages for all of your projects. Author your page content here using GitHub Flavored Markdown, select a template crafted by a designer, and publish. After your page is generated, you can check out the new branch:

```
$ cd your_repo_root/repo_name
$ git fetch origin
$ git checkout gh-pages
```

If you're using the GitHub for Mac, simply sync your repository and you'll see the new branch.

### Designer Templates
We've crafted some handsome templates for you to use. Go ahead and continue to layouts to browse through them. You can easily go back to edit your page before publishing. After publishing your page, you can revisit the page generator and switch to another theme. Your Page content will be preserved if it remained markdown format.

### Rather Drive Stick?
If you prefer to not use the automatic generator, push a branch named `gh-pages` to your repository to create a page manually. In addition to supporting regular HTML content, GitHub Pages support Jekyll, a simple, blog aware static site generator written by our own Tom Preston-Werner. Jekyll makes it easy to create site-wide headers and footers without having to copy them across every page. It also offers intelligent blog support and other advanced templating features.

### Authors and Contributors
You can @mention a GitHub username to generate a link to their profile. The resulting `<a>` element will link to the contributor's GitHub Profile. For example: In 2007, Chris Wanstrath (@defunkt), PJ Hyett (@pjhyett), and Tom Preston-Werner (@mojombo) founded GitHub.

### Support or Contact
Having trouble with Pages? Check out the documentation at http://help.github.com/pages or contact support@github.com and weâ€™ll help you sort it out.
